title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: presenting field trial layouts, â€™s often important provide spatial context orientation arrows (indicating north directions) annotations reference physical features field (boundaries, gates, adjacent landmarks). vignette demonstrates add elements field layout plots generated biometryassist package. biometryassist package generates field layout plots ggplot2 objects, means can enhance using standard ggplot2 functions extensions. vignette show : Add orientation arrows arbitrary rotation Add text annotations outside plotting area label field features

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: First, letâ€™s load required packages generate basic experimental design:   design() function creates field layout stores des.$plot.des ggplot2 object. can now enhance plot additional annotations.
code: library(biometryassist) library(ggplot2) library(ggspatial)  # Generate a completely randomized design (CRD) des.out <- design(   type = "crd",    treatments = c(1, 5, 10, 20),   reps = 5,    nrows = 4,    ncols = 5,    seed = 42 ) Source of Variation                     df ============================================= treatments                              3 Residual                                16 ============================================= Total                                   19 # View the basic plot des.out$plot.des

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: Orientation arrows help readers understand spatial layout field trial relative cardinal directions reference points. particularly useful field orientation affects environmental conditions like sun exposure prevailing winds.

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: ggspatial package provides annotation_north_arrow() function, specifically designed adding directional arrows plots. â€™s primarily intended spatial data coordinate reference systems, works well field layout plots .  Letâ€™s break component code: annotation_north_arrow() arguments: location = "tr": Places arrow top-right corner. options include "tl" (top-left), "bl" (bottom-left), "br" (bottom-right), can specify exact coordinates numeric vector c(x, y). rotation = 45: Rotates arrow 45 degrees clockwise north. allows indicate true field orientation. example, north field 45 degrees clockwise top plot, use rotation = 45. Use rotation = 0 north aligns top plot. pad_x = unit(-1.5, "cm"): Moves arrow horizontally. Negative values move left, positive values move right. allows fine-tuning arrow position. pad_y = unit(0.5, "cm"): Moves arrow vertically. Positive values move , negative values move . style = north_arrow_fancy_orienteering(): Specifies visual style arrow. available styles include: north_arrow_minimal(): Simple arrow design north_arrow_nautical(): Compass-style design north_arrow_orienteering(): Classic orienteering map style Within style function, can customize: line_width: Thickness arrow lines text_size: Size â€œNâ€ label Additional ggplot2 modifications: coord_cartesian(clip = ""): critical. default, ggplot2 clips (cuts ) elements fall outside plotting area. Setting clip = "" allows arrow drawn outside plot panel, necessary using padding position beyond plot boundaries. theme(plot.margin = ...): Expands margins around plot create space arrow. margin() function takes four values: top, right, bottom, left. Units specified unit parameter (, points). increase right margin 50pt accommodate arrow.
code: des.out$plot.des +    annotation_north_arrow(     location = "tr",     rotation = 45,     pad_x = unit(-1.5, "cm"),     pad_y = unit(0.5, "cm"),     style = north_arrow_fancy_orienteering(       line_width = 1,       text_size = 10     )   ) +   coord_cartesian(clip = "off") +   theme(plot.margin = margin(t = 10, r = 50, b = 10, l = 10, unit = "pt"))

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: can customize arrow style parameters match needs:
code: des.out$plot.des +    annotation_north_arrow(     location = "tr",     rotation = 30,  # Different rotation angle     pad_x = unit(-1, "cm"),     pad_y = unit(0.3, "cm"),     style = north_arrow_minimal(  # Different style       line_width = 1.5,       text_size = 12     )   ) +   coord_cartesian(clip = "off") +   theme(plot.margin = margin(t = 10, r = 50, b = 10, l = 10, unit = "pt"))

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: addition orientation, â€™s often helpful label physical features field site, boundaries, access points, adjacent landmarks. annotations provide practical context field operations help trial management.

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: annotate() function allows us add text (geometric objects) specific locations plot. Unlike north arrow, annotations use plotâ€™s coordinate system.  Letâ€™s examine annotation detail: First annotation - â€œBoundary Roadâ€ (vertical text right): "text": Specifies â€™re adding text annotation (options include "rect", "segment", etc.) x = 5.8: x-coordinate text. Since plot 5 columns (numbered 1-5), placing 5.8 positions outside right edge plot. y = mean(des.$design$row): Centers text vertically calculating mean row numbers. ensures text centered regardless number rows. label = "Boundary Road": text display. angle = 270: Rotates text 270 degrees (-90 degrees), making read bottom top. conventional labels right side plots. hjust = 0.5: Horizontal justification. 0.5 centers text horizontally relative x-coordinate. vjust = -0.5: Vertical justification. Negative values move text away plot (outward), positive values move toward plot. ensures text doesnâ€™t overlap plot area. size = 6: font size text. Second annotation - â€œGateâ€ (horizontal text top): x = 1.5: Positions text column 1.5 (columns 1 2). y = 5: Places top row (row 4), outside plotting area. angle specified, text remains horizontal (0 degrees). parameters work similarly first annotation. Critical settings external annotations: xlim ylim explicitly set visible data range. essential add annotations coordinates outside data range (like x = 5.8), ggplot2 normally expand axis limits include points, stretching plot. explicitly setting limits match original plot grid (columns 0.5-5.5, rows 0.5-4.5), prevent expansion. clip = "" allows drawing outside limits, annotations x = 5.8 y = 5 still visible. theme(plot.margin = ...): Expands margins create physical space text. right margin set 70pt accommodate â€œBoundary Roadâ€, top margin 20pt â€œGateâ€.
code: des.out$plot.des +    annotate(     "text",     x = 5.8,     y = mean(des.out$design$row),     label = "Boundary Road",     angle = 270,     hjust = 0.5,     vjust = -0.5,     size = 6   ) +   annotate(     "text",     x = 1.5,     y = 5,     label = "Gate",     hjust = 0.5,     vjust = -0.5,     size = 6   ) +   coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0.5, 5.5), ylim = c(0.5, 4.5), clip = "off") +   theme(plot.margin = margin(t = 10, r = 70, b = 20, l = 10, unit = "pt"))

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: field layout plot uses row column numbers coordinates: - Columns numbered 1 ncols (, 1 5) - Rows numbered 1 nrows (, 1 4) - plot cell centered integer coordinates position annotations: - Outside right edge: Use x > max column number (e.g., x = 5.8 max column 5) - Outside top edge: Use y > max row number (e.g., y = 5 max row 4) - Outside left edge: Use x < min column number (e.g., x = 0.2 min column 1) - Outside bottom edge: Use y < min row number (e.g., y = 0.2 min row 1)

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: can add many annotations needed chaining multiple annotate() calls:
code: des.out$plot.des +    annotate("text", x = 5.8, y = mean(des.out$design$row),             label = "Boundary Road", angle = 270, hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 6) +   annotate("text", x = 1.5, y = 5,             label = "Gate", hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 6) +   annotate("text", x = 0.2, y = mean(des.out$design$row),             label = "Irrigation Line", angle = 90, hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 5) +   annotate("text", x = mean(des.out$design$col), y = 0.2,             label = "Drainage Ditch", hjust = 0.5, vjust = 1, size = 5) +   coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0.5, 5.5), ylim = c(0.5, 4.5), clip = "off") +   theme(plot.margin = margin(t = 20, r = 70, b = 30, l = 50, unit = "pt"))

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: can combine techniques create fully annotated field layout:
code: des.out$plot.des +    # Add north arrow   annotation_north_arrow(     location = "tr",     rotation = 45,     pad_x = unit(-1.5, "cm"),     pad_y = unit(0.5, "cm"),     style = north_arrow_fancy_orienteering(line_width = 1, text_size = 10)   ) +   # Add field feature annotations   annotate("text", x = 5.8, y = mean(des.out$design$row),             label = "Boundary Road", angle = 270, hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 6) +   annotate("text", x = 1.5, y = 5,             label = "Gate", hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 6) +   # Apply coordinate system and theme adjustments   coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0.5, 5.5), ylim = c(0.5, 4.5), clip = "off") +   theme(plot.margin = margin(t = 20, r = 70, b = 20, l = 10, unit = "pt"))

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: find right coordinates annotations: Check design dimensions: Use str(des.$design) see row column ranges Use summary functions: mean(), min(), max() help center position annotations Experiment iteratively: Start approximate values adjust based output

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: annotations cut far plot: Increase margin text cut : margin(t = 30, r = 80, ...) Decrease margin â€™s much white space: margin(t = 10, r = 40, ...) Margins specified : top, right, bottom, left

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: angle = 0: Horizontal text (default) angle = 90: Vertical text, reading bottom--top angle = 270 angle = -90: Vertical text, reading top--bottom (conventional right-side labels) angle = 45: Diagonal text (sometimes useful corner annotations)

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: hjust = 0: Left-aligned hjust = 0.5: Center-aligned (common) hjust = 1: Right-aligned vjust = 0: Bottom-aligned vjust = 0.5: Middle-aligned vjust = 1: Top-aligned external annotations, vjust values outside 0-1 (like vjust = -0.5) create spacing text plot edge.

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: techniques work design type generated biometryassist. â€™s example randomized complete block design (RCBD):   Note coordinate limits (xlim ylim) adjusted match dimensions design (4 columns, 6 rows).
code: # Generate an RCBD des.rcbd <- design(   type = "rcbd",   treatments = LETTERS[1:6],   reps = 4,   nrows = 6,   ncols = 4,   brows = 6,   bcols = 1,   seed = 123 ) Source of Variation                     df ============================================= Block stratum                           3 --------------------------------------------- treatments                              5 Residual                                15 ============================================= Total                                   23 # Add annotations des.rcbd$plot.des +   annotation_north_arrow(     location = "tr",     rotation = 0,     pad_x = unit(-1, "cm"),     pad_y = unit(0.5, "cm"),     style = north_arrow_minimal(line_width = 1, text_size = 10)   ) +   annotate("text", x = 4.8, y = mean(des.rcbd$design$row),            label = "Access Road", angle = 270, hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5, size = 5) +   coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0.5, 4.5), ylim = c(0.5, 6.5), clip = "off") +   theme(plot.margin = margin(t = 10, r = 60, b = 10, l = 10, unit = "pt"))

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: Solution: Increase relevant plot margin using theme(plot.margin = margin(...)). Ensure margins large enough accommodate text.

what: Problem: Plot is stretched or distorted
title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: Solution: using annotate() coordinates outside plot range, always specify explicit limits coord_cartesian(xlim = ..., ylim = ...) prevent automatic axis expansion.

what: Problem: North arrow is not visible
title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: Solution: 1. Check coord_cartesian(clip = "") included 2. Verify plot margins large enough 3. Adjust pad_x pad_y values position arrow within margin area

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: Solution: Adjust angle parameter: - right side labels reading upward: angle = 90 - right side labels reading downward (conventional): angle = 270 - left side labels: reverse angles

title: Adding Orientation Arrows and Annotations to Field Layout Plots
text: Adding orientation arrows field feature annotations experimental design plots enhances utility field management, reporting, publication. combination ggspatial::annotation_north_arrow() directional reference ggplot2::annotate() custom labels provides flexible tools creating publication-ready field layout diagrams. Remember key principles: - Use coord_cartesian(clip = "") allow drawing outside plot panel - Set appropriate plot.margin values create space external elements - annotate(), explicitly set xlim ylim prevent axis stretching - Experiment positioning adjust iteratively

code: autoplot(object, ...)  # S3 method for class 'mct' autoplot(   object,   size = 4,   label_height = 0.1,   rotation = 0,   axis_rotation = rotation,   label_rotation = rotation,   type = "point",   ... )  # S3 method for class 'design' autoplot(   object,   rotation = 0,   size = 4,   margin = FALSE,   palette = "default",   row = NULL,   column = NULL,   block = NULL,   treatments = NULL,   legend = TRUE,   ... )

title: Generate automatic plots for objects generated in biometryassist â€” autoplot
text: object object create plot . Currently objects multiple_comparisons() design() functions class "mct" "design" respectively supported. ... Arguments passed methods. size Increase decrease text size within plot treatment labels. Numeric default value 4. label_height Height text labels upper error bar plot. Default 0.1 (10%) difference upper lower error bars top error bar. Values > 1 interpreted actual value upper error bar. rotation Rotate x axis labels treatment group labels within plot. Allows easier reading long axis treatment labels. Number 0 360 (inclusive) - default 0 axis_rotation Enables rotation x axis independently group labels within plot. label_rotation Enables rotation treatment group labels independently x axis labels within plot. type string specifying type plot display. default 'point' display point estimate error bars. alternative, 'column' ('col'), display column graph error bars. margin Logical (default FALSE). value FALSE expand plot edges plotting area .e. remove white space plot axes. palette string specifying colour scheme use plotting vector custom colours use palette. Default equivalent "Spectral". Colour blind friendly palettes can also provided via options "colour blind" ("colour blind", equivalent "viridis"), "magma", "inferno", "plasma", "cividis", "rocket", "mako" "turbo". palettes scales::brewer_pal() also possible. row variable plot column object rows. column variable plot column object columns. block variable plot column object blocks. treatments variable plot column object treatments. legend Logical (default TRUE). TRUE, displays legend treatment colours.

title: Generate automatic plots for objects generated in biometryassist â€” autoplot
code: dat.aov <- aov(Petal.Width ~ Species, data = iris) output <- multiple_comparisons(dat.aov, classify = "Species") autoplot(output, label_height = 0.5)  des.out <- design(type = "crd", treatments = c(1, 5, 10, 20),                   reps = 5, nrows = 4, ncols = 5, seed = 42, plot = FALSE) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> treatments                              3 #> Residual                                16 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   19 autoplot(des.out)   # Colour blind friendly colours autoplot(des.out, palette = "colour-blind")   # Alternative colour scheme autoplot(des.out, palette = "plasma")   # Custom colour palette autoplot(des.out, palette = c("#ef746a", "#3fbfc5", "#81ae00", "#c37cff"))   # Visualise different components of a split plot design des.out <- design(type = "split", treatments = c("A", "B"), sub_treatments = 1:4, reps = 4, nrows = 8, ncols = 4, brows = 4, bcols = 2, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                          df #> ================================================== #> Block stratum                                3 #> -------------------------------------------------- #> Whole plot stratum #>          treatments                          1 #> Whole plot Residual                          3 #> ================================================== #> Subplot stratum #>          sub_treatments                      3 #>          treatments:sub_treatments           3 #>          Subplot Residual                   18 #> ================================================== #> Total                                       31   # Show the wholeplot components autoplot(des.out, treatments = wholeplots)   # Display block level autoplot(des.out, treatments = block)

One crd, rcbd, lsd, split, strip, crossed factorial specified crossed:<base> <base> one crd, rcbd, lsd. treatments vector containing treatment names labels. split-plot designs, treatments applied whole-plots. strip-plot designs, treatments applied row-strips (entire rows within block receive treatment). reps number replicates. Ignored Latin Square Designs. nrows number rows design. ncols number columns design. brows RCBD, split-plot strip-plot designs. number rows block. bcols RCBD, split-plot strip-plot designs. number columns block. byrow split-plot strip-plot designs. Logical (default TRUE). Controls within-block arrangement multiple valid layouts. sub_treatments vector treatments sub-plot factor (required split strip). strip-plot designs, treatments applied column-strips (entire columns within block receive treatment). apply treatments columns instead rows, swap treatments sub_treatments arguments. fac.names Allows renaming level factorial designs passing (optionally named) vectors new labels applied factors within list. See examples details information. fac.sep separator used fac.names. Used combine factorial design levels. vector 2 levels supplied, first separates factor levels label, second separates different factors. buffer string specifying buffer plots include plotting. Default NULL (buffers plotted). options "edge" (outer edge trial area), "rows" (rows), "columns" (columns), "double row" (buffer row side treatment row) "double column" (buffer row side treatment column). "blocks" (buffer around treatment block) implemented future release. plot Logical (default TRUE). TRUE, display plot generated design. plot can always produced later using autoplot(). rotation Rotate text output Treatments within plot. Allows easier reading long treatment labels. Takes positive negative values number degrees rotation horizontal. size Increase decrease text size within plot treatment labels. Numeric default value 4. margin Logical (default FALSE). Expand plot edges plotting area .e. remove white space plot axes. save One FALSE (default)/"none", TRUE/"", "plot" "workbook". Specifies output save. savename file name design saved . Default type design combined "_design". plottype type file save plot . Usually one "pdf", "png", "jpg". See ggplot2::ggsave() possible options. seed Logical (default TRUE). TRUE, return seed used generate design. numeric value, use value seed design. quiet Logical (default FALSE). Hide output. ... Additional parameters passed ggplot2::ggsave() saving plot.

title: Create a complete experimental design with graph of design layout and skeletal ANOVA table â€” design
text: list containing data frame complete design ($design), ggplot object plot layout ($plot.des), seed ($seed, return.seed = TRUE), satab object ($satab), allowing repeat output satab table via cat(output$satab).

title: Create a complete experimental design with graph of design layout and skeletal ANOVA table â€” design
text: Supported designs Completely Randomised (crd), Randomised Complete Block (rcbd), Latin Square (lsd), split-plot (split), strip-plot (strip), crossed factorial designs via crossed:<base> <base> crd, rcbd, lsd (e.g. crossed:crd). save = TRUE (""), plot workbook saved current working directory, filename given savename. one either "plot" "workbook" specified, output saved. save = FALSE (default, equivalently "none"), nothing output. fac.names can supplied provide intuitive names factors levels factorial split plot designs. can specified list format, example fac.names = list(A_names = c("", "b", "c"), B_names = c("x", "y", "z")). result design output column named A_names levels , b, c another named B_names levels x, y, z. Labels can also supplied character vector (e.g. c("", "B")) result treatment column names renamed. first two elements list used, except case 3-way factorial design. ... allows extra arguments passed ggsave() output plot. details possible arguments can found  ggplot2::ggsave().

title: Create a complete experimental design with graph of design layout and skeletal ANOVA table â€” design
code: # Completely Randomised Design des.out <- design(type = "crd", treatments = c(1, 5, 10, 20),                   reps = 5, nrows = 4, ncols = 5, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> treatments                              3 #> Residual                                16 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   19   # Randomised Complete Block Design des.out <- design("rcbd", treatments = LETTERS[1:11], reps = 4,                   nrows = 11, ncols = 4, brows = 11, bcols = 1, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> Block stratum                           3 #> --------------------------------------------- #> treatments                              10 #> Residual                                30 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   43   # Latin Square Design # Doesn't require reps argument des.out <- design(type = "lsd", c("S1", "S2", "S3", "S4"),                   nrows = 4, ncols = 4, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> Row                                     3 #> Column                                  3 #> treatments                              3 #> Residual                                6 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   15   # Factorial Design (Crossed, Completely Randomised) des.out <- design(type = "crossed:crd", treatments = c(3, 2),                   reps = 3, nrows = 6, ncols = 3, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> A                                       2 #> B                                       1 #> A:B                                     2 #> Residual                                12 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   17   # Factorial Design (Crossed, Completely Randomised), renaming factors des.out <- design(type = "crossed:crd", treatments = c(3, 2),                   reps = 3, nrows = 6, ncols = 3, seed = 42,                   fac.names = list(N = c(50, 100, 150),                                    Water = c("Irrigated", "Rain-fed"))) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> N                                       2 #> Water                                   1 #> N:Water                                 2 #> Residual                                12 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   17   # Factorial Design (Crossed, Randomised Complete Block Design), # changing separation between factors des.out <- design(type = "crossed:rcbd", treatments = c(3, 2),                   reps = 3, nrows = 6, ncols = 3,                   brows = 6, bcols = 1,                   seed = 42, fac.sep = c(":", "_")) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> Block stratum                           2 #> --------------------------------------------- #> A                                       2 #> B                                       1 #> A:B                                     2 #> Residual                                10 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   17   # Factorial Design (Nested, Latin Square) trt <- c("A1", "A2", "A3", "A4", "B1", "B2", "B3") des.out <- design(type = "lsd", treatments = trt,                   nrows = 7, ncols = 7, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> Row                                     6 #> Column                                  6 #> treatments                              6 #> Residual                                30 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   48   # Split plot design des.out <- design(type = "split", treatments = c("A", "B"), sub_treatments = 1:4,                   reps = 4, nrows = 8, ncols = 4, brows = 4, bcols = 2, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                          df #> ================================================== #> Block stratum                                3 #> -------------------------------------------------- #> Whole plot stratum #>          treatments                          1 #> Whole plot Residual                          3 #> ================================================== #> Subplot stratum #>          sub_treatments                      3 #>          treatments:sub_treatments           3 #>          Subplot Residual                   18 #> ================================================== #> Total                                       31   # Alternative arrangement of the same design as above des.out <- design(type = "split", treatments = c("A", "B"), sub_treatments = 1:4,                   reps = 4, nrows = 8, ncols = 4, brows = 4, bcols = 2,                   byrow = FALSE, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                          df #> ================================================== #> Block stratum                                3 #> -------------------------------------------------- #> Whole plot stratum #>          treatments                          1 #> Whole plot Residual                          3 #> ================================================== #> Subplot stratum #>          sub_treatments                      3 #>          treatments:sub_treatments           3 #>          Subplot Residual                   18 #> ================================================== #> Total                                       31   # Strip plot design des.out <- design(type = "strip", treatments = c("A", "B", "C"), sub_treatments = 1:4,                   reps = 4, nrows = 12, ncols = 4, brows = 3, bcols = 4, seed = 42) #> Source of Variation                     df #> ============================================= #> Block stratum                           3 #> --------------------------------------------- #> treatments                              2 #> treatments Residual                     6 #> sub_treatments                          3 #> sub_treatments Residual                 9 #> treatments:sub_treatments               6 #> Interaction Residual                    18 #> ============================================= #> Total                                   47

title: Produce a heatmap of variables in a grid layout. â€” heat_map
code: set.seed(42) dat <- expand.grid(x = 1:5, y = 1:6) dat$value <- rnorm(30) dat$groups <- sample(rep(LETTERS[1:6], times = 5))  heat_map(dat, value, x, y)   # Column names can be quoted, but don't need to be. heat_map(dat, "value", "x", "y", "groups")   # Different palettes are available heat_map(dat, value, x, y, palette = "Spectral")   # \donttest{ # Arguments in ... are passed through to facet_wrap heat_map(dat, value, x, y, groups, labeller = ggplot2:::label_both)  heat_map(dat, value, x, y, groups, scales = "free_y")  heat_map(dat, value, x, y, groups, nrow = 1)  # }

text: model.obj ASReml-R aov model object. likely also work lme (nlme::lme()), lmerMod (lme4::lmer()) models well. classify Name predictor variable string. sig significance level, numeric 0 1. Default 0.05. int.type type confidence interval calculate. One ci, tukey, 1se, 2se, none. Default ci. trans Transformation applied response variable. One log, sqrt, logit, power, inverse, arcsin. Default NULL. offset Numeric offset applied response variable prior transformation. Default NULL. Use 0 offset applied transformed data. See Details information. power Numeric power applied response variable power transformation. Default NULL. See Details information. decimals Controls rounding decimal places output. Default 2 decimal places. descending Logical (default FALSE). Order output sorted predicted value. TRUE, largest first, smallest last. groups Logical (default TRUE). TRUE, significance letter groupings calculated displayed. can get overwhelming large numbers comparisons, can turned setting FALSE. plot Automatically produce plot output multiple comparison test? Default FALSE. maintained backwards compatibility, preferred method now use autoplot(<multiple_comparisons output>). See autoplot.mct() details. label_height Height text labels upper error bar plot. Default 0.1 (10%) difference upper lower error bars top error bar. rotation Rotate text output Treatments within plot. Allows easier reading long treatment labels. Number 0 360 (inclusive) - default 0 save Logical (default FALSE). Save predicted values csv file? savename file name predicted values saved . Default predicted_values. order Deprecated. Use descending instead. pred.obj Deprecated. Predicted values calculated within function version 1.0.1 onwards. pred Deprecated. Use classify instead. ... arguments passed get_predictions().

title: Perform Multiple Comparison Tests on a statistical model â€” multiple_comparisons
text: function provides several options confidence intervals via int.type argument: ci (default): Traditional confidence intervals individual means. estimate precision individual mean may align multiple comparison results. Non-overlapping traditional confidence intervals necessarily indicate significant differences multiple comparison tests. tukey: Tukey comparison intervals consistent multiple comparison test. intervals wider regular confidence intervals designed non-overlapping intervals correspond statistically significant differences Tukey HSD test. ensures visual consistency intervals letter groupings. 1se 2se: Intervals Â±1 Â±2 standard errors around mean. none: confidence intervals calculated displayed plots. default, function displays regular confidence intervals (int.type = "ci"), estimate precision individual treatment means. However, performing multiple comparisons, regular confidence intervals may align letter groupings Tukey's HSD test. Specifically, may observe non-overlapping confidence intervals treatments share letter group (indicating significant difference). occurs regular confidence intervals Tukey's HSD test serve different purposes: Regular confidence intervals estimate individual mean precision Tukey's HSD controls family-wise error rate across pairwise comparisons resolve visual inconsistency, can use Tukey comparison intervals (int.type = "tukey"). intervals specifically designed multiple comparisons consistent letter groupings: non-overlapping Tukey intervals indicate significant differences, overlapping intervals suggest significant difference. function issue message detects potential inconsistencies non-overlapping confidence intervals letter groupings, suggesting use Tukey intervals clearer interpretation. multiple comparison contexts, Tukey comparison intervals recommended provide visual consistency statistical test performed avoid common confusion traditional confidence intervals overlap groups share significance letter.

title: Perform Multiple Comparison Tests on a statistical model â€” multiple_comparisons
text: JÃ¸rgensen, E. & Pedersen, . R. (1997). Obtain Nasty Standard Errors Transformed Data - Used. https://pure.au.dk/portal/en/publications/--obtain--nasty-standard-errors--transformed-data-

title: Perform Multiple Comparison Tests on a statistical model â€” multiple_comparisons
code: # Fit aov model model <- aov(Petal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)  # Display the ANOVA table for the model anova(model) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Response: Petal.Length #>            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)     #> Species     2 437.10 218.551  1180.2 < 2.2e-16 *** #> Residuals 147  27.22   0.185                       #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 â€˜***â€™ 0.001 â€˜**â€™ 0.01 â€˜*â€™ 0.05 â€˜.â€™ 0.1 â€˜ â€™ 1  # Determine ranking and groups according to Tukey's Test (with Tukey intervals) pred.out <- multiple_comparisons(model, classify = "Species")  # Display the predicted values table pred.out #> Multiple Comparisons of Means: Tukey's HSD Test #> Significance level: 0.05  #> HSD value: 0.20378  #>  #> Predicted values: #>      Species predicted.value std.error  df groups   ci  low   up #> 1     setosa            1.46      0.06 147      a 0.12 1.34 1.58 #> 2 versicolor            4.26      0.06 147      b 0.12 4.14 4.38 #> 3  virginica            5.55      0.06 147      c 0.12 5.43 5.67  # Access the p-value matrix pred.out$pairwise_pvalues #>                  setosa   versicolor    virginica #> setosa     1.000000e+00 2.997602e-15 2.997602e-15 #> versicolor 2.997602e-15 1.000000e+00 2.997602e-15 #> virginica  2.997602e-15 2.997602e-15 1.000000e+00  # Access the HSD value pred.out$hsd #> [1] 0.20378  # Show the predicted values plot autoplot(pred.out, label_height = 0.5)   # Use traditional confidence intervals instead of Tukey comparison intervals pred.out.ci <- multiple_comparisons(model, classify = "Species", int.type = "ci") pred.out.ci #> Multiple Comparisons of Means: Tukey's HSD Test #> Significance level: 0.05  #> HSD value: 0.20378  #>  #> Predicted values: #>      Species predicted.value std.error  df groups   ci  low   up #> 1     setosa            1.46      0.06 147      a 0.12 1.34 1.58 #> 2 versicolor            4.26      0.06 147      b 0.12 4.14 4.38 #> 3  virginica            5.55      0.06 147      c 0.12 5.43 5.67  # Plot without confidence intervals pred.out.none <- multiple_comparisons(model, classify = "Species", int.type = "none") autoplot(pred.out.none)   # AOV model example with transformation my_iris <- iris my_iris$Petal.Length <- exp(my_iris$Petal.Length) # Create exponential response exp_model <- aov(Petal.Length ~ Species, data = my_iris)  resplot(exp_model) # Residual plot shows problems   # Fit a new model using a log transformation of the response log_model <- aov(log(Petal.Length) ~ Species, data = my_iris)  resplot(log_model) # Looks much better   # Display the ANOVA table for the model anova(log_model) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Response: log(Petal.Length) #>            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)     #> Species     2 437.10 218.551  1180.2 < 2.2e-16 *** #> Residuals 147  27.22   0.185                       #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 â€˜***â€™ 0.001 â€˜**â€™ 0.01 â€˜*â€™ 0.05 â€˜.â€™ 0.1 â€˜ â€™ 1  # Back transform, because the "original" data was exponential pred.out <- multiple_comparisons(log_model, classify = "Species",                                    trans = "log") #> Warning: Offset value assumed to be 0. Change with `offset` argument.  # Display the predicted values table pred.out #> Multiple Comparisons of Means: Tukey's HSD Test #> Significance level: 0.05  #> HSD value: 0.20378  #>  #> Predicted values: #>      Species predicted.value std.error  df groups   ci PredictedValue ApproxSE #> 1     setosa            1.46      0.06 147      a 0.12           4.31     0.26 #> 2 versicolor            4.26      0.06 147      b 0.12          70.81     4.31 #> 3  virginica            5.55      0.06 147      c 0.12         257.75    15.69 #>      low     up #> 1   3.83   4.87 #> 2  62.79  79.86 #> 3 228.54 290.69  # Show the predicted values plot autoplot(pred.out, label_height = 15)   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # ASReml-R Example library(asreml)  #Fit ASReml Model model.asr <- asreml(yield ~ Nitrogen + Variety + Nitrogen:Variety,                     random = ~ Blocks + Blocks:Wplots,                     residual = ~ units,                     data = asreml::oats)  wald(model.asr) # Nitrogen main effect significant  #Determine ranking and groups according to Tukey's Test pred.out <- multiple_comparisons(model.obj = model.asr, classify = "Nitrogen",                     descending = TRUE, decimals = 5)  pred.out  # Example using a box-cox transformation set.seed(42) # See the seed for reproducibility resp <- rnorm(n = 50, 5, 1)^3 trt <- as.factor(sample(rep(LETTERS[1:10], 5), 50)) block <- as.factor(rep(1:5, each = 10)) ex_data <- data.frame(resp, trt, block)  # Change one treatment random values to get significant difference ex_data$resp[ex_data$trt=="A"] <- rnorm(n = 5, 7, 1)^3  model.asr <- asreml(resp ~ trt,                     random = ~ block,                     residual = ~ units,                     data = ex_data)  resplot(model.asr)  # lambda = 1/3 from MASS::boxcox() model.asr <- asreml(resp^(1/3) ~ trt,                     random = ~ block,                     residual = ~ units,                     data = ex_data)  resplot(model.asr) # Look much better  pred.out <- multiple_comparisons(model.obj = model.asr,                                  classify = "trt",                                  trans = "power", power = (1/3))  pred.out autoplot(pred.out, label_height = 0.5) } # }
